PlottedLocation_Note: Rev. John Ashton was posted at the White Marsh plantation. Sacred Heart Church now stands where the White Marsh chapel used to be.
Notes: See Jay P Dolan, The American Catholic Experience (1985), p 87 for location of White Marsh farm, where Ashton lived. He is listed as a subscriber in "Selections from the Correspondence of the Deceased Mathew Carey . . . .," Records of the American Catholic Historical Society of Philadelphia, Vol. 9, American Catholic Historical Society of Philadelphia, 1898, p. 363.
SK_Notes: Year of birth approximate. Jesuit missionary; slave owner; one of the founders of Georgetown University. Source (including a lot on his relationship with the enslaved people): https://msa.maryland.gov/msa/speccol/sc5400/sc5496/041700/041715/html/041715.html
Network: Rev. John Lewis; Rev. James Walton; Rev. Robert Molyneaux; Rev. John Carroll

PlottedLocation_Note: Rev. Franciso Beeston, S.J., was Superior at Bohemia from 1790 to 1793. See Joseph C. Cann, History of Saint Francis Xavier Church and Bohemia Plantation, Now Known as Old Bohemia, Warwick, Maryland (Bohemia Plantation: The Society, 1976), p. 151.
Notes: SK: "Bohemia" refers to the Bohemia mission in MD, not the place in the Czech Republic.
SK_Notes: http://jesuitarchives.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/woodstock-063.pdf
Network: Bohemia Plantation. Later Baltimore. John Carroll eulogized Beeston as one "with whom he had long resided, and by whom he was constantly aided and relieved in his arduous offices, whom he cherished as a faithful counsellor and companion." See E. I. Devitt, “Bohemia: Mission of St. Francis Xavier, Cecil County, Maryland,” Records of the American Catholic Historical Society of Philadelphia 24, no. 2 (1913): 97–139.

Notes: There are two by this name, neither from Baltimore.
SK_Notes: Just one Richard Bennett comes up in my search of the 1790 census. In 1796, there is a newspaper notice about the land of "the late Mr. Richard Bennett," but that land is in Frederick County: https://www.newspapers.com/image/41044882/?terms=%22Richard%2BBennett%22

Notes: doesn't appear in 1790 census
SK_Notes: His last name is spelled differently in different sources, e.g. Bevens in a newspaper ad re: selling his property in 1813 (upon his death), see here: https://www.washcolibrary.org/assets/documents/HagerstownNewspapers1810-1814.pdf. In the 1800 census, a Leonard Bevins is living 20 miles west of Hagerstown, so likely the same guy. Also: "In 1808 Leonard Bevans, a resident of the area, donated one and one quarter acre of land to the Roman Catholic Diocese of Baltimore 'for the better convenience and advantage of the Roman Catholics residing in the neighborhood of Fifteen Mile Creek.'" Source: MD Historical Trust Inventory Form for State Historic Sites Survey, https://mht.maryland.gov/secure/medusa/PDF/Allegany/AL-I-A-054.pdf

PlottedLocation_Note: Blakeford was the home of Chalres Blake. The original building has burned, by MD Historical Trust records identify the mansion's approximate location. See Edward B. Carley, The Origins and History of St. Peter's Church, Queenstown, Maryland, 1637-1976 (Centerville, MD: Carley, 1976), p. 30.
SK_Notes: Pretty certain the Blakes are the owners of Blakeford, MD. If that is the case, there is quite a bit about this family, including how this Charles lost the estate. See here: https://msa.maryland.gov/megafile/msa/speccol/sc5800/sc5881/000001/000000/000200/pdf/msa_sc_5881_1_200.pdf. In 1790, a Chales Blake was sailing the Wye River with his two sons "and a negro boy" in addition to another man and his son when the boat overturned. The men and one of the boys survived, but the two younge sons and the black boy drowned: https://www.newspapers.com/image/38353176/?terms=%22Charles%2BBlake%22
Network: Married Henrietta Marie Lloyd and John Sayer Blake was their son. There is a parish document from 1781 where John, Charles, and Henrietta all become godparents to various christened children: http://mdhistory.msa.maryland.gov/msa_sc2677/msa_sc2677_scm858/pdf/msa_sc2677_scm858-0222.pdf

Notes: He also appears in the 1800 census, same address; add one to the Queen Anne's County count.
SK_Notes: He likely lived in what was known as Wye-River, MD, just southeast of Blakeford, MD.

Notes: doesn't appear in 1790 census
SK_Notes: A woodworker with a connection to George Washington.
Network: William Fitzhugh, George Washington. "William Fitzhugh, George Platerês friend and stepfather-inlaw, had recommended Richard Boulton to George Washington as a craftsman whose work equaled the best. Boulton is credited with the design and supervision of the expansion of Sotterley that created an elegant entry hall and drawing room around 1770 as well as with work on other residences and churches in St. Maryês County. Boulton signed a contract with George Washington in May 1785 to finish the large room at the north end of the first floor at Mount Vernon. Washington had undertaken to send a wagon to pick up Boultonês tools at Sotterley. However, Boulton wrote back almost immediately saying he could not fulfill the contract because his creditors threatened to have him arrested if he tried to leave Maryland. Plater did not himself endorse Fitzhughês recommendation nor write Washington about Boulton."Fitzhugh writes a letter to GW regretting the recommendation.  Source: https://msa.maryland.gov/megafile/msa/speccol/sc2900/sc2908/000001/000864/pdf/am864.pdf#search=richard%20boulto p. 147-148.

PlottedLocation_Note: The property Baker Brooke had owned would become the sight of the first convent of religious women in America (Mount Carmel), founded 4 miles from Port Tobacco in 1790. Brooke was paid for the land, but he gave the house to the order and to Rev. Charles Neale as a present.
Notes: He is listed as a subscriber in "Selections from the Correspondence of the Deceased Mathew Carey . . . .," Records of the American Catholic Historical Society of Philadelphia, Vol. 9, American Catholic Historical Society of Philadelphia, 1898, p. 368. His location there is "Charles City," but in Carey's published list, it's "Charles county," which is what I'm using.
Network: Rev. Charles Neale (also a subscriber) bought the property for the first American women's convent in 1790 (and was given a house on it as a present by Baker Brooke). This book has a ton on the relationship between Brooke and the order and Charles/Francis Neale: https://books.google.com/books?id=JO3PAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA150&dq=%22baker+brooke%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi7l8PepcTbAhWPGDQIHUG3A3wQ6AEIRjAF#v=onepage&q=%20brooke%22&f=false

SK_Notes: He was at Rock Creek, which is now Forest Glen, MD, according to this biography (p. 53): https://books.google.com/books?id=8zcjYPZxPV0C&pg=PA53&dq=%22daniel+carroll%22+%22rock+creek%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwio6fqd4s7bAhUO8YMKHRK1CFUQ6AEITjAH#v=onepage&q=%22daniel%20carroll%22%20%22rock%20creek%22&f=false
NumberSlaves: One of the largest slave owners in the country
Network: Older brother of Bishop John Carroll, cousin of Charles Carroll, friend of George Washington, member of the Maryland State Senate, signer of the Constitution of the United States. In 1791, Washington appointed him to the commission to determine the exact location of the District of Columbia, which ended up being almost exclusively on Daniel Carroll's land. Source: p. 50-53 https://books.google.com/books?id=8zcjYPZxPV0C&pg=PA53&dq=%22daniel+carroll%22+%22rock+creek%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwio6fqd4s7bAhUO8YMKHRK1CFUQ6AEITjAH#v=onepage&q=%22daniel%20carroll%22%20%22rock%20creek%22&f=false

See Sister Mary Louise Donnelly, William Elder: Ancestors and Descendants (1986), p 21-22. He was born 1745 and died in 1812. He lived in Frederick Co all his life. He was a farmer and a slave owner.

PlottedLocation: 8855 Chapel Point Rd, Port Tobacco, MD

Notes: Rev. Francis Neale lived at St. Thomas Manor, near Port Tobacco, until 1792, when he was assigned to Georgetown. See William W. Warner, At Peace with All Their Neighbors: Catholics and Catholicism in the National Capital 1787-1860 (1994), 20. He is also listed as a subscriber in "Selections from the Correspondence of the Deceased Mathew Carey . . . .," Records of the American Catholic Historical Society of Philadelphia, Vol. 9, American Catholic Historical Society of Philadelphia, 1898, p. 366.
SK_Notes: A lot of primary documents on him here: https://books.google.com/books?id=JO3PAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA150&dq=%22baker+brooke%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi7l8PepcTbAhWPGDQIHUG3A3wQ6AEIRjAF#v=onepage&q=%22baker%20brooke%22&f=false

PlottedLocation: 11555 St Marys Church Rd, Charlotte Hall, MD 20622
PlottedLocation_Note: Rev. Henry Pile was stationed at the Newport Mission in 1784 or 1785 and served as pastor there until 1813. According to the Maryland Historical trust, the site of the mission was where St. Mary's Catholic Church is located now.
Notes: He is listed as a subscriber in "Selections from the Correspondence of the Deceased Mathew Carey . . . .," Records of the American Catholic Historical Society of Philadelphia, Vol. 9, American Catholic Historical Society of Philadelphia, 1898, p. 363. On p 360 Carroll identifies Pile's location as "Newport, Charles County."

Network: Newport mission since 1785; St. Thomas Manor (where he died)

PlottedLocation_Note: Plowden's father mentions the name of his manor ("Resurrection Manor") in his will and leaves the manor and the land specifically to Edmund.

When Rev. Robert Plunkett sailed to the United States in 1790 along with Rev. Charles Neal, he was posted at the White Marsh plantation. Sacred Heart Church now stands where the White Marsh chapel used to be.
Notes: I found this location--White Marsh, MD--from Robert Emmett Curran, A History of Georgetown University, vol I (Washington, DC, 2010): 34.
SK_Notes: The last name is Plunkett in multiple sources
Network: First president of Georgetown; White Marsh Plantation

PlottedLocation_Note: Location approximate. The Calvin B. Taylor House Museum locates John Postly's land between the towns of Berlin and St. Martin.
Notes: SK: I found different census numbers - 1 male, 4 females, 14 slaves
SK_Notes: Also: he might actually be a Presbyterian, at least according to this: https://taylorhousemuseum.org/history/john-postly/
Network: His will was supposed to _benefitt of and to be applied toward the necessities or Education of poor necessitous young people in the bounds of Buckingham and Worcester Hundreds in Worcester County - http://aomol.msa.maryland.gov/000001/000214/html/am214--259.html

In 1800, Chalres Pye and Sarah Pye donate land to John Mondesir, pastor of the Conwallis's Neck congregation to build a church there - http://www.colonial-settlers-md-va.us/getperson.php?personID=I020841&tree=tree1

PlottedLocation: Queens Chapel Rd NE, Washington, DC 20018
PlottedLocation_Note: The "Records of Columbia Historical Society" places Queen's Chapel in Richard Queen's estate, "situated amid the wooden hills of Langdon." See John B. Larner, ed., "Records of the Columbia Historical Society," Vol. 23 (Washington: The Society, 1920), p. 30.
Notes: He is listed as a subscriber in "Selections from the Correspondence of the Deceased Mathew Carey . . . .," Records of the American Catholic Historical Society of Philadelphia, Vol. 9, American Catholic Historical Society of Philadelphia, 1898, p. 366. His location is "Eastern branch of the Potowmack." This could place him in modern-day Washington, DC, but I've decided to leave him located in the county, per the census.
Network: His will leaves to the "Right Rev. John Carroll --Bishop of Baltimore -the remaining members of the Catholic Church to have 2 acres of land where the Catholic chapel now sits being a part of a tract of land called "The Inclosure" and testator's intention is that it be used for the religious purposes of the Catholic Church and congregation and executors are to measure and bound the 2 acres of land w/in 12 months after testator's decease and the lands to exclude as much as possible all public roads" - http://www.colonial-settlers-md-va.us/getperson.php?personID=I034879&tree=Tree1

PlottedLocation: Bloomingdale Road & Ocean Gateway (US 50), Queenstown, MD 21658
PlottedLocation_Note: Edward B. Carley ("The Origins and History of St. Peter's Church, Queenstown, Maryland, 1637-1976") places Charles Seth at Island Creek, and another source confirms this location with the further specification of Mount Mills. Mount Mills used to be where Bloomingdale is now.

Nicholas Lewis Sewall was known as "Nicholas Lewis of Cedar Point." The St. Nicholas Catholic Church at Cedar Point was named in honor of Sewall's father Nicholas Sewall, owner of the Mattapany plantation.
Notes: 2 Nicholas Sewalls in 1790 census Marylan (SK: he's the one with the L. for middle name). A Nicholas Sewall, Jr. appears in St Mary's County, MD in 1790, on a voter list (which is the county in which Cedar Point is located). He is listed as a subscriber in "Selections from the Correspondence of the Deceased Mathew Carey . . . .," Records of the American Catholic Historical Society of Philadelphia, Vol. 9, American Catholic Historical Society of Philadelphia, 1898, p. 363. His location is listed as appears in the published list.
Network: Brother of Charles Sewall. http://www.colonial-settlers-md-va.us/getperson.php?personID=I017846&tree=Tree1

PlottedLocation_Note: Location approximate. Rev. John Ambrose Souge writes a letter about coming to St. Joseph's mission in 1802 and says that John Bolton (who was in charge of the mission) usually stayed with Robert Tuite and that Tuite frequently supplied communion wine , which means that Tuite resided not too far from the mission. See the full letter in Edward B. Carley, The Origins and History of St. Peter's Church, Queenstown, Maryland, 1637-1976 (Centerville, MD: Carley, 1976), p. 47-48.
Joseph Agonito in "The Building of an American Catholic Church: The Episcopacy of John Carroll" (New York: Routledge, 2017) places James Van Huffel in St. Mary's County.
Notes: doesn't appear in 1790 census
Network: Was at John Carroll's first national synod - https://books.google.com/books?id=5B8FAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA429&dq=%22Rev+james+Van+Huffel%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj33uvtouXbAhUMY6wKHaPUBakQ6AEIKTAA#v=onepage&q=%22Rev%20james%20Van%20Huffel%22&f=false

Notes: 4 Ignatius Wheelers in 1790 census Maryland; SK: only one in St Mary's County
SK_Notes: There is a wealthy Catholic by the name of Ignatius Wheeler residing in Hartford County as well; he is likely the same person, but I have no definitive proof; and St. Mary's and Hartford Counties are quite far away, so why would the location be off in the subscriber list? Ignatius Wheeler shows up again on another list of John Carroll's, this one re: Georgetown, and in that list, Carroll specifies that Wheeler is "on the Western shore," but again, inconclusive as to the exact location.
